body.p: The MHC complex is loosely referred to as your tissue type. The cells in the immune system early in development must learn to distinguish self from non-self. It is is important to try to match tissue types when someone needs a bone marrow or organ transplant. Why is tissue type important for you everyday immune function? Pick the answer that is not a normal function of MHC proteins.

multiple_choice.choice: T lymphocytes will react to viral proteins expressed on the surface of the cell that also expresses the appropriate MHC proteins
Immune cells may be able to recognize a mutated or precancerous cells that is expressing the correct MCH proteins on its surface with some other abnormal or mutated protein
Antibodies only work in the organism that made them
The correct MHC proteins expressed on the surface of a cell along with new or unusual proteins signal a potential threat

feedback.p: Incorrect. This is an important part of your body’s defense against viruses

Incorrect. This function is believed to be an important part of controlling cancer. As people age their immune function declines which may be why the incidence of cancer in general increases with increasing age

Correct. Antibodies can be passed from one individual to another often referred to as passive immunity. This is how mothers help give their newborns some immunity until the baby’s immune system mature
Incorrect. Your body needs to determine self vs. non-self as part of its ongoing threat assessment.

body.p: Unless someone is an identical twin, they have a unique configuration of proteins on the surfaces of the cells. These proteins termed___________________ are inherited from your parents., However, you only get a few from each parent not the full range the parent has. Consequently, siblings may not have exactly identical ________________ meaning they will not always be a _______________ for a transplant. This group of proteins is different from your ________________ which is a different group of proteins found on your red blood cells.

multiple_choice.choice: sister chromatids, tissue types, compatible donor, Rh factor
major histocompatiblity complex antigens, blood type, compatible donor, blood type
major histocompatiblity complex antigens, tissue type, compatible donor, blood type
blood proteins, transplant type, incompatible donor, donor ID

feedback.p: Incorrect. Sister chromatids are found in the nucleus during meiosis and the Rh factor is only one of several proteins which contribute to blood type.
Incorrect. The MHC proteins make up your tissue type not your blood type.
Correct. Tissue type and blood type are two different systems of cell identification. Donors and transplant patients should have the same blood types and tissue types as closely matching as possible.
Incorrect. MHC proteins are found on somatic tissue cells not blood cells.
